RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Covestro LLC

SOUTH CHARLESTON MANUFACTURING PLANT



April 12,2017





a.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Covestro LLC is committed to and comply with the requirements of the Responsible Care Management System (RCMS) which emphasize operating in a safe and environmentally correct manner. Management systems are in place to assure all facilities are complying with these principles.  There are Corporate Engineering Standards and Health, Environment and Safety Guidelines which address every aspect of Risk Management from design of intrinsically safe processes to the use of risk assessment, incident tracking and program audits. Covestro LLC was formerly a division of Bayer AG, but is now a separate company and is classified as a subsidiary of BayerAG since Bayer owns a majority of the Covestro stock. Covestro is headquartered in Leverkusen, Germany. The US (country) headquarters for Covestro is located in Pittsburgh, PA.  Covestro LLC has its own company structure, policies and procedures which are consistent with those of the holding company, but are customized to meet local regulations and standards.  Covestro has established guidelines for Responsible Care in Environmental Protection and Safety, which include a Directive for Process and Plant Safety that all Covestro facilities world-wide are expected to follow.  It provides guidance for safe process design and operation.



In the US, Covestro LLC is an active member of the American Chemistry Council's Responsible Care Initiative.  Covestro has implemented all seven codes (Pollution Prevention, Distribution, Product Stewardship, Employee health & Safety, Security: and Community Awareness & Emergency Response) of management practice.  Covestro has a Health, Safety, Environment and Quality Policy which states that it is the company's responsibility to protect the environment and the health and safety of its employees, customers and communities.

This is a primary responsibility, of equal importance to any other business objective.  This is supported in the Covestro LLC Visions, Values and Beliefs, which emphasize applying technical expertise to advance our business while assuring the safety and protection of our employees, customers, communities and the environment.



The Covestro South Charleston facility has implemented all of the corporate Health Environment and Safety Policies and Guidelines through site policies and procedures.  These include site Safety and Health Procedures, Emergency Response Procedures, Process Safety Management Procedures, Hazard Communication Procedures and Risk Management Procedures as well as safety plans in the individual production unit operating procedures.



In addition, Covestro South Charleston facility uses the following measures to assure the safety of its chemical processes:



ENGINEERING and DESIGN



* Detailed operating procedures

* Special safety standards (Operation Safety Standards)

* Special equipment standards

* Special piping and valves

* Remotely operated isolation valves

* State of the art computerized controls

* Redundant & energy protected controls

* Dual independent high level alarms

* Automatic shut down of filling operations on receipt of high level alarm

* Control Room protection during emergencies

* Continuous improvement of processes & equipment

* Management of Change procedures

* Color coding and labeling of piping & vessels

* Dikes and curbs to contain spills 

* Production units designed to withstand natural disasters



DETECTION



* Selected area monitors for flammables

* Portable monitors for leak detection

* Surveillance cameras



TRAINING



* Refresher and safety training for all employees

* New employee qualification requirements

* Emergency response drills

* Specialized maintenance skills training

* Worker certification programs

* Off-site specialized training for emergency response teams



INSPECTIONS and SAFET

Y REVIEWS



* Incident investigations and reviews

* Systematic equipment inspection

* Critical instrument and pressure relief valve inspections

* Process Hazard Analyses every 5 years

* Extensive fugitive emissions monitoring program

* Regular safety audits of all operating units

* Tracking system for recommendations



MEDICAL MANAGEMENT



* Certified EMT's on each shift

* Medical procedures coordinated with local hospitals



MITIGATION



* Release containment equipment and materials

* Release containment procedures

* Extensive area water sprinkler system

* Foam vapor suppression capability



EMERGENCY RESPONSE



* Trained emergency response teams

* Written emergency action plans

* Emergency teams maintained on all shifts

* Emergency alarm systems for units, plant, and community

* Coordination with Kanawha Putnam LEPC, South Charleston Fire Department and other Local Agencies



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



* Periodic review of operating procedures

* Covestro employees are members of all emergency teams and along with host site people make up 100% of the squad

* Employees participate on incident investigation teams

* Employees (hourly and salaried) participate on multiple safety committees



b. Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled



The primary activities at the South Charleston facility are the production of Polyols which are used in the manufacture of polyurethanes.  The Polyols that are manufactured are either as Polyether (Flex) Polyols or Polymer Polyols.  The RMP chemicals used in the manufacture of Flex Polyols are propylene oxide and ethylene oxide. The RMP chemical used in the manufacture of Polymer Polyols is acrylonitrile.  Vinylidene chloride (RMP flammable chemical) was previoulsy used in Polymer Polyol manufacture, but is no longer used.  In summary the Covestro South Charleston facility has three (3) RMP listed toxic chemicals. All three RMP toxic chemicals were modeled using worst case release parameters as a s

creening exercise to determine the distance to toxic endpoint.   Acrylonitrile has the worst toxic case scenario (distance to toxic endpoint) followed in order of potential off-site impact by ethylene oxide and propylene oxide.  

c.  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The South Charleston Plant complies with all elements of the OSHA PSM Rule and the EPA RMP Rule.  There are safety procedures, standard operation emergency procedures, accident investigations, hot work and line opening permits, extensive training programs, on-site emergency response teams, vessel inspection programs, and experienced personnel both in the salaried and hourly workforce.  



d.   Five Year Accident History



There have been no releases in the past five years with off-site consequences.  Since the initial implementation of the RMP rule there have been no offsite impacts from release of RMP chemicals from the South Charleston manufacturing facility. 



e.  Facility Emergency Response Program



The South Charleston Emergency Response System consists of volunteer emergency response teams from Covestro and the host company that work rotating shifts and straight days.  The goal is to have 3 to 6 emergency squad members always available on shift and this group is supplemented by straight day people, call outs and the South Charleston Fire Department.  The Covestro and the host site emergency squad people receive approximately 16 to 24 hours of on-site training annually with some disciplines receiving off-site training as well in specialized subjects, such as fire fighting, rescue, incident command and Hazmat.  In the case of a significant fire the South Charleston Fire department would likely be involved.  The plant also participates in local fire and industrial mutual aid systems through the Kanawha Putnam Emergency Planning Committee (KPEPC).

Community warning sirens are placed in multiple places in the Kanawha Valley and there is one within 1

mile of the plant. 



The South Charleston Plant maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response including:



* Proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures 

* Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation

* Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs

* Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements, and

* Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment.



The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.



f.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety



* Installation of additional surveillance cameras

* Replacement of multiple water fire sprinkler systems in process areas

* Addition of addition sprinkler system in acrylonitrile tank car unloading area

* Installation of a foam suppression system in one process area

* Completion/implementation of maintenance certification program for training
